course_title: Special Topics in Economics: Economics of Crime
seats: Seats: Maximum Enrollment: 20 / Seats Avail: 7Waitlist Total: 0
class_notes: This course examines criminal behavior through the lens of economics with an emphasis on empirical methodology. The goal of the course is to develop a framework for analyzing criminal behavior and related policies as well as improve empirical literacy to better understand data and public information related to crime. In addition to discussing theoretical models of behavior, individual topics will include crime trends and measurement, impacts of policing and incarceration, gun violence and gun control, drug markets and prohibition, sex work, and discrimination. This is a discussion-based course. Academic papers will be regularly assigned to be read for discussion in the subsequent session.
course_description: Selected topics in Economics. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.
prerequisites: This course requires ECON _OX 100 or ECON 101 or ECON_OX 101 or FIN 201 AND ECON 112  or ECON_OX112 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.
